abstract.t: This document outlines a protocol and file formats for payments using Bitcoin-derived cryptocurrencies such as Dogecoin. This protocol is intended to simplify the payment processing from the perspective of the customer, as well as reducing scope for user error.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Currently cryptocurrency payment solutions suffer from a number of issues:

list.t: They often require the user to manually cut & paste the payment address and amount.
There is no verification of the origin of a payment request
There is no integrity check on a payment request to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks
There is no automated solution for providing refund addresses as part of a payment
The receiving user or system may have to poll to check for payments, instead of receiving notification when payment is sent

section.t: The Dogecoin payment protocol addresses these issues by automating much of the payment negotiation process. The protocol defines a sequence of messages to be exchanged between the merchant server and user's client software.
The Dogecoin payment protocol is intended for use with the Dogecoin cryptocurrency, however should be usable with most Bitcoin-derived cryptocurrencies with no modification.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.
An implementation is not compliant if it fails to satisfy one or more of the MUST or REQUIRED level requirements for the protocols it implements.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: This specification uses a number of terms to refer to elements of cryptocurrency technology:

list.t: A hashed public key, which can be used as an endpoint to send cryptocurrency to.
The public ledger of transactions made within a cryptocurrency.
The server of the person or organisation payment is to be sent to
An instruction to change ownership of coins, stored within the blockchain.
The software client of the person sending payment.

section.title: Outline
section.t: The payment protocol exchanges three messages between the merchant server and the wallet software:

list.t: Retrieved by the wallet client. Defines the amount to be paid, how payment should be made, and the endpoint to notify when payment has been sent.
Sent by the wallet client to the merchant server once payment has been sent. Specifies the transaction(s) which form the payment, as well as details of where to refund payment to if necessary.

Returned to the wallet client from the merchant server in response to the Payment message. Acknowledges receipt of the Payment message, and current state of the transactions as seen by the merchant server.

section.t: This document describes payment over HTTP as a transport layer. Other transport layers (such as NFC) are left for future work.
The default payment protocol steps are as follows:

list.t: Merchant server prompts user for payment
User initiates payment (for example opens a URL link)
Wallet client downloads the PaymentRequest message from the merchant server
Wallet client prompts user to confirm the payment
User confirms payment
Wallet client sends payment in accordance to instructions in PaymentRequest
Wallet client sends Payment message to merchant server, describing how payment was sent
Merchant server returns PaymentACK message to indicate Payment message has been received

section.title: Message Format
section.t: All messages are in the JSON format (RFC 7159
